elements.content: The reaction of a conjugated bispyridyl-based Schiff base ligand L (L = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) with transition metal ions afforded two different structure types of coordination polymers depending on the choice of counteranions. The combination of ZnII or MnII acetate and L in solution yielded two novel infinite one-dimensional (1D) molecular ladder complexes 1 and 2 with a molecular composition of [M2 L 2(OAc)4·2(MeOH)] n , (M = ZnII or MnII), in which acetate anions serve as bridges. However, when replacing ZnII or MnII acetate with ZnII or CdII nitrate in the same reaction condition, two isomorphous 1D linear coordination polymers 3 and 4 with a molecular composition of [ML(NO3)2(H2O)2] n , (M = ZnII or CdII) were obtained. Interestingly, the 1D polymeric chains of 3 and 4 could be further assembled to a three-dimensional (3D) microporous cross-like array with layer-to-layer alternate arrangement resulting from interchain π···π stacking and hydrogen-bonding interactions with the presence of coordinated nitrate anions and water molecules. There are remarkably distinct coordination and molecular packing modes in the two types of complexes regardless of the nature of the metal ions used. These results indicate that the nature of the anions, which play different roles in forming two types of crystals, is the key factor directing the structural topologies. IR spectra and thermal behaviors of all four complexes have been characterized, and photoluminescent studies revealed that the ZnII and CdII complexes were fluorescent with medium intensity in the solid state.

elements.content: Four novel coordination polymers consisting of two types of molecular architectures have been fabricated based on the anion-controlled self-assembly from a bidentate Schiff base ligand. Acetate anion induced the formation of two one-dimensional (1D) metal−organic molecular ladder compounds, while nitrate anion resulted in the isolation of two three-dimensional metal−organic cross-like arrays based on the orderly organization of a 1D polymeric chain. All four complexes were characterized by UV−vis and IR spectra, TGA and XRPD analyses, and photoluminescence measurements.

Acetate anion induced the formation of two one-dimensional (1D) metal-organic molecular ladder compounds, while nitrate anion resulted in the isolation of two three-dimensional metal-organic cross-like arrays based on the orderly organization of a 1D polymeric chain. All four complexes were characterized by UV-vis and IR spectra, TGA and XRPD analyses, and photoluminescence measurements.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the synthesis and characterization of four novel coordination polymers consisting of two types of molecular architectures based on the anion-controlled self-assembly from a simple bidentate Schiff base ligand. Acetate anions induced the formation of two 1D metal−organic molecular ladder compounds, while nitrate anions resulted in the isolation of two 3D metal−organic cross-like arrays based on the orderly organization of 1D polymeric chains. The results confirmed that counteranions with different coordination modes could play an important role in governing the crystal engineering. All four complexes were well characterized by UV−vis and IR spectra, TGA and XRPD analyses, and photoluminescence measurements.

The results confirmed that counteranions with different coordination modes could play an important role in governing the crystal engineering. All four complexes were well characterized by UV-vis and IR spectra, TGA and XRPD analyses, and photoluminescence measurements.

elements.content: The study of inorganic−organic hybrid polymer materials has recently attracted considerable interest not only for their great potential applications in the areas of photonic, electronic, magnetic, microporous, and biomimetic materials but also for their versatile topologic structures for aesthetic appeals. One of the ultimate goals of supramolecular chemistry is to control the structure of the target products with desired properties and functions, which mainly depends on the spontaneous assembly of molecular compositions through the earlier studies. To date, of some elegant efforts to find the key factors in the approach to the desired metallosupramolecules, the rational strategy has been the utility of various spacer ligands as the “building block”.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of inorganic-organic hybrid polymer materials has recently attracted considerable interest not only for their great potential applications in the areas of photonic, electronic, magnetic, microporous, and biomimetic materials but also for their versatile topologic structures for aesthetic appeals. One of the ultimate goals of supramolecular chemistry is to control the structure of the target products with desired properties and functions, which mainly depends on the spontaneous assembly of molecular compositions through the earlier studies. To date, of some elegant efforts to find the key factors in the approach to the desired metallosupramolecules, the rational strategy has been the utility of various spacer ligands as the "building block".

elements.content: A vast majority of metal-based supramolecular frameworks already have been generated with 4,4‘-bipyridyl-based ligands. Although it has been elaborated that the rational design and subtle choice of organic building blocks as well as metal coordination sites have proved to be very significant in controlling the solid-state structures of the target products, to establish the general and precise principles of constructing desirable framework topologies is still a large challenge. Some factors such as metal ions with distinct binding nature, counteranions, solvents, metal−ligand ratio, pH value, and even reaction temperature have been found to remarkably influence the structural topologies of the resultant coordination frameworks. In particular, the role of anions in self-assembly processes has emerged as an increasingly active theme in recent studies. Our recent efforts on controlled coordination-driven self-assembly of pyrrole-based polyamine ligands also shed some lights on this point.
elements.clean_text: A vast majority of metal-based supramolecular frameworks already have been generated with 4,4‘-bipyridyl-based ligands. Although it has been elaborated that the rational design and subtle choice of organic building blocks as well as metal coordination sites have proved to be very significant in controlling the solid-state structures of the target products, to establish the general and precise principles of constructing desirable framework topologies is still a large challenge. Some factors such as metal ions with distinct binding nature, counteranions, solvents, metal-ligand ratio, pH value, and even reaction temperature have been found to remarkably influence the structural topologies of the resultant coordination frameworks. In particular, the role of anions in self-assembly processes has emerged as an increasingly active theme in recent studies. Our recent efforts on controlled coordination-driven self-assembly of pyrrole-based polyamine ligands also shed some lights on this point.

elements.content: On the other hand, in contrast to the development of flexible 4,4‘-donor bridging ligands, efforts on the relatively rigid, long π-conjugated analogues of 4,4‘-bipyridine, 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L) are still scarce (Scheme ). In fact, only three metal complexes built from this ligand, [Ag(L)NO3] n , [Co(L)1.5(NO3)2(H2O)(CH2Cl2)2] n , and [Ni(L)2(NO3)2(OC4H8)1.66(H2O)0.33] n , were reported recently. In their extended frameworks, nitrate anions and solvent molecules seem readily to coordinate to the metal centers or cocrystallize within the resultant complexes, which play a crucial role in driving the formation of multidimensional framework architectures. To further our understanding of the controlled assembly of metallosupramolecules, we studied the role of counteranions in directing the self-assembly behavior of supramolecular complexes based on L. In this work, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, and properties of a series of transition metal complexes with L, which exhibit two different types of topologies. In each case, the reaction conditions (solvent, temperature, and metal−ligand ratio) are kept constant, and only the metals (ZnII, MnII, and CdII) with nitrate or acetate anions are varied. The key role of anions in tuning the resultant structural topologies has been concluded. The thermal behaviors and photoluminescent properties of these coordination polymers have also been studied preliminarily.

The thermal behaviors and photoluminescent properties of these coordination polymers have also been studied preliminarily.

General. All starting materials were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, and solvents were purified according to standard methods before use. Ligand L was synthesized by a previously reported procedure and well characterized. Samples for C, H, N analyses were performed with a Carlo Erba-1106 instrument. UV−vis absorption spectra measurements were obtained on a Hitachi UV-3010 absorption spectrophotometry. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a BIO-RAD FT-165 IR spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescent emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometry. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a Dupont 951 thermogravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected using monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General. All starting materials were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, and solvents were purified according to standard methods before use. Ligand L was synthesized by a previously reported procedure and well characterized. Samples for C, H, N analyses were performed with a Carlo Erba-1106 instrument. UV-vis absorption spectra measurements were obtained on a Hitachi UV-3010 absorption spectrophotometry. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a BIO-RAD FT-165 IR spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescent emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-2500 fluorescence spectrophotometry. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a Dupont 951 thermogravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected using monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of Complex 1. A solution of L (0.210 g, 1 mmol) in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was slowly added to a solution of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.220 g, 1 mmol) in 5 mL of MeOH under stirring. The resulting mixture was left standing for two weeks at room temperature to give light yellow single crystals of 1. Yield:  80%, UV−vis(CHCl3), λmax/nm:  281, 303, 318, 350 (broad shoulder). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3395w, 1951s, 1605m, 1402s, 1335s, 1231s, 1032s, 968s, 818s, 683s, 515s. Anal. Calcd for C16H16N4O4Zn·CH3OH:  C, 47.96; H, 4.73; N, 13.16. Found:  C, 47.31; H, 4.64; N, 13.16.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Suitable single crystals of 1−4 were selected and mounted onto thin glass fibers in air. Accurate unit cell parameters were determined by a least-squares fit of 2θ values, measured for 200 strong reflections, and intensity data sets were measured on Bruker Smart 1000 CCD or Rigaku Raxis Rapid IP diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, but no corrections for extinction were made. All structures were solved by direct methods. The non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier synthesis. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were added theoretically and riding on the concerned atoms. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structure analyses are summarized in Table . Relevant interatomic bond distances and bond angles for 1−4 are given in Table .

Synthesis and Characterization. Ligand L (Scheme ) is a long conjugated and rigid bidentate Schiff base ligand, which is readily synthesized in high yield according to the literature method. Reaction of L with equimolar transition metals acetate or nitrate under the same condition resulted in the isolation of single crystals of complexes 1−4 in high yields. The UV−vis absorption spectra revealed the occurrence of coordination interactions of metal-to-ligand in solution due to the appearance of an additional broad shoulder absorption in all cases. In the IR spectra of complexes 1−4, the broad band centered at ca. 3400 cm-1 indicates the O−H stretching of the crystalline methanol molecules (in 1 and 2) and aqua molecules (in 3 and 4) correlated to the structural analyses as described below. The IR spectra for 1 (2) display the characteristic bands of the acetate anions at 1605 (1597) cm-1 for νas(C - O), 1402 (1406) cm-1 for νsym(C - O), and 683 (680) cm-1 for δO - C - O. For 3 and 4, the characteristic bands of the nitrate anions appear at 1384 and 1398 cm-1 for νas(NO2) with very strong intensity, 1227 and 1233 cm-1 for νsym(NO2), and then 1027 and 1033 cm-1 for ν(NO), respectively. The νas − νsym values are 157 and 165 cm-1, respectively, suggesting the monodentate binding feature of NO3 - anions when coordinated to the metal centers.

Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Characterization. Ligand L (Scheme ) is a long conjugated and rigid bidentate Schiff base ligand, which is readily synthesized in high yield according to the literature method. Reaction of L with equimolar transition metals acetate or nitrate under the same condition resulted in the isolation of single crystals of complexes 1-4 in high yields. The UV-vis absorption spectra revealed the occurrence of coordination interactions of metal-to-ligand in solution due to the appearance of an additional broad shoulder absorption in all cases. In the IR spectra of complexes 1-4, the broad band centered at ca. 3400 cm-1 indicates the O-H stretching of the crystalline methanol molecules (in 1 and 2) and aqua molecules (in 3 and 4) correlated to the structural analyses as described below. The IR spectra for 1 (2) display the characteristic bands of the acetate anions at 1605 (1597) cm-1 for νas(C - O), 1402 (1406) cm-1 for νsym(C - O), and 683 (680) cm-1 for δO - C - O. For 3 and 4, the characteristic bands of the nitrate anions appear at 1384 and  1398 cm-1 for νas(NO2) with very strong intensity, 1227 and 1233 cm-1 for νsym(NO2), and then 1027 and 1033 cm-1 for ν(NO), respectively. The νas - νsym values are 157 and 165 cm-1, respectively, suggesting the monodentate binding feature of NO3 - anions when coordinated to the metal centers.

elements.content: Structures of Molecular Ladders (1 and 2). The X-ray structural analyses revealed that the coordination complexes 1 and 2 were isomorphous. Interestingly, two structures contain the same neutral molecular compositions of [M2 L 2(OAc)4·2(MeOH)] n and adopt the polymeric structures of infinite molecular ladders, despite having different metal centers (Scheme ). Several ladder-like supramolecular structures based on coordination-driven self-assembly have been reported previously; an interesting multiple interpenetration phenomenon based on 1D molecular ladders was typically found in the extended 3D packing structures. Our results herein exhibit a facile approach to simple anion-bridging molecular ladders without the occurrence of interpenetration. In complex 1, each zinc ion is coordinated to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two discrete ligands, resulting in the formation of a linear polymeric chain. One acetate anion strongly chelates to the metal center with two Zn−O bonds, while another acetate anion plays an essential role in constructing the bilayered polymeric chain, a well-defined 1D molecular ladder, with a bridging coordination mode. Figure a shows the coordination environment of ZnII centers and bridging mode of the molecular ladder. Each ZnII center is hexa-coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms from three acetate anions. The Zn−N distances are 2.160(2) and 2.188(2) Å, respectively. The angle of N−Zn−N is 176.16(7)°, indicating a nearly linear geometry for a single polymeric chain. One acetate anion chelates to the metal center with the carboxylate group, while two other acetate anions bind to two distinct metal centers and serve as bridges to connect two adjacent single chains with a parallel pattern (Figure b). The Zn−O distances between the metal centers and the acetate anions are all in the range of 2.022−2.134 Å, comparable to the usual Zn−O bond distances reported, while a relatively weak Zn−O bond also exists with Zn(1)−O(4) = 2.400 Å. The separation of two adjacent zinc atoms bridged by acetate anions is 3.927 Å, and two parallel ligands thus interact with each other by weak π···π overlay of two conjugated ligand molecules (the distance of centroid−centroid of two pyridine rings is ca. 3.801 Å). In addition, the crystalline methanol molecules are fixed at two sides of the molecule ladder by strong O−H···O hydrogen bonds between methanol and coordinated acetate, and also the methanolic oxygen atoms interact with the methylene-H from another molecular ladder in another direction, leading to the C−H···O hydrogen bonds (Table ). The packing pattern of the ladder-like arrays shows another interesting point. As seen from Figure c, the single 1D molecule ladder arranges one by one in a parellel fashion to form a molecular layer, then these layer and other layers in a nearly perpendicular direction are organized alternately to a 3D array through bridging methanol molecules.
elements.clean_text: Structures of Molecular Ladders (1 and 2). The X-ray structural analyses revealed that the coordination complexes 1 and 2 were isomorphous. Interestingly, two structures contain the same neutral molecular compositions of [M2 L 2(OAc)4⋅2(MeOH)] n  and adopt the polymeric structures of infinite molecular ladders, despite having different metal centers (Scheme ). Several ladder-like supramolecular structures based on coordination-driven self-assembly have been reported previously; an interesting multiple interpenetration phenomenon based on 1D molecular ladders was typically found in the extended 3D packing structures. Our results herein exhibit a facile approach to simple anion-bridging molecular ladders without the occurrence of interpenetration. In complex 1, each zinc ion is coordinated to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two discrete ligands, resulting in the formation of a linear polymeric chain. One acetate anion strongly chelates to the metal center with two Zn-O bonds, while another acetate anion plays an essential role in constructing the bilayered polymeric chain, a well-defined 1D molecular ladder, with a bridging coordination mode. Figure a shows the coordination environment of ZnII centers and bridging mode of the molecular ladder. Each ZnII center is hexa-coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms from three acetate anions. The Zn-N distances are 2.160(2) and 2.188(2) Å, respectively. The angle of N-Zn-N is 176.16(7)°, indicating a nearly linear geometry for a single polymeric chain. One acetate anion chelates to the metal center with the carboxylate group, while two other acetate anions bind to two distinct metal centers and serve as bridges to connect two adjacent single chains with a parallel pattern (Figure b). The Zn-O distances between the metal centers and the acetate anions are all in the range of 2.022-2.134 Å, comparable to the usual Zn-O bond distances reported, while a relatively weak Zn-O bond also exists with Zn(1)-O(4) = 2.400 Å. The separation of two adjacent zinc atoms bridged by acetate anions is 3.927 Å, and two parallel ligands thus interact with each other by weak π⋅⋅⋅π overlay of two conjugated ligand molecules (the distance of centroid-centroid of two pyridine rings is ca. 3.801 Å). In addition, the crystalline methanol molecules are fixed at two sides of the molecule ladder by strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between methanol and coordinated acetate, and also the methanolic oxygen atoms interact with the methylene-H from another molecular ladder in another direction, leading to the C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (Table ). The packing pattern of the ladder-like arrays shows another interesting point. As seen from Figure c, the single 1D molecule ladder arranges one by one in a parellel fashion to form a molecular layer, then these layer and other layers in a nearly perpendicular direction are organized alternately to a 3D array through bridging methanol molecules.

Structures of 3D Cross-like Arrays (3 and 4). When we used metal nitrate, Zn(NO3)2 and Cd(NO3)2, instead of acetate, two 3D cross-like supramolecular arrays (3 and 4) based on single molecular chains were isolated (Scheme ). The X-ray structural analyses revealed that complexes 3 and 4 were also isomorphous, and two structures contain the same molecular compositions of [ML(NO3)2(H2O)2] n (M = ZnII or CdII). Both complexes adopt a relatively simple 1D coordination mode due to the existence of the strongly coordinated nitrate anions, which occupy the remaining coordination sites of ZnII or CdII ions and inhibit the formation of extended 2D or 3D coordination frameworks as reported for the common bispyridyl-based metal complexes. Figure a displays the coordination environment of ZnII centers in complex 3. Each ZnII center adopts octahedral coordination geometry with two nitrogen donors from two symmetrically related ligands, four oxygen donors from two nitrate anions, and two water molecules, respectively. The two Zn−N distances are virtually equivalent (ca. 2.097 Å), and the N−Zn−N angle is 180.00(13)°, indicating a perfect linear geometry, similar to the cases in complexes 1 and 2. The Zn−O distance between the nitrate anion and ZnII is 2.191(2) Å, while the Zn−O separation from coordinated water to ZnII is 2.143(3) Å. The repeating unit is further extended to a 1D chainlike polymer along the symmetry center, and all the aromatic rings of the single polymeric chain are overall coplanar, which favors an orderly multilayered arrangement (Figure b,c).

elements.content: The most remarkable feature of the packing pattern in complexes 3 and 4 is that the subtle combination of π···π stacking and hydrogen-bonding interactions serves to connect the 1D coordination chain to a 3D cross-like array. First, the nearly cross-like arrangement and the well coplanarity of the 1D polymeric chains are responsible for the occurrence of the π···π stacking interactions between the adjacent polymeric chains. The closest C−C distance of two pyridine rings in 3 is 3.642 Å, falling in the general π···π stacking distances. The hydrogen bond resulting from both adjacent and alternate polymeric chains is the second factor for the 3D packing. As shown in Figure b, the coordinated water molecules serve as proton donors and nitrate anions serve as proton acceptors, contributing to the strong O−H···O hydrogen bonds. The general O···O distances are in the range of 2.864−2.941 Å. Table lists the common hydrogen-bonding distances and angles existing in complexes 3 and 4.

The hydrogen bond resulting from both adjacent and alternate polymeric chains is the second factor for the 3D packing. elements.content: Figure c displays clearly the herringbone packing mode based on the self-assembly of the single-chain polymers with interchain interactions, in which lots of molecular pores exist with a dimensionality of ca. 6.0 × 9.5 Å, and the porous channels in the 3D structure are not empty; rather, the coordinated nitrate anions and water molecules partially fill the channels and contribute well to the stability of the 3D solids. The topology of the porous 3D array can be illustrated as Scheme ; the polymeric chains organize together orderly in an ABAB... fashion to form the 3D network with large molecular channels. Although 3D multilayer noninterpenetrating networks do not represent unusual structure forms among the self-assembled metal−organic coordination compounds, there are rare examples of 3D microporous networks constructed directly from 1D polymeric chains in a mutually perpendicular mode without the occurrence of interpenetration reported in the literature.

Thermal Behavior and Photoluminescence. We investigated the thermal stability of four coordination polymers. TGA analyses were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of each compound. All samples were heated at a rate of 10 °C/min under flowing N2 atmosphere. TGA data revealed that all four complexes suffered a weight loss of ca. 7−8% at low temperature, owing to the removal of crystalline methanol or coordinated water molecules (see Supporting Information). Then complexes 1 and 2 underwent gradual decomposition upon further heating, while the dehydrated samples of 3 and 4 remained stable up to 250 °C before fully decomposing to unidentified products. Furthermore, the most intense peaks observed in the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns from the bulk samples of 1−4 are consistent with those calculated from single-crystal diffraction data. The peaks were maintained well even after all the incorporated solvents were removed from the lattice, indicating high stability of the 3D microporous network backbones (Supporting Information).

Furthermore, the most intense peaks observed in the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns from the bulk samples of 1-4 are consistent with those calculated from single-crystal diffraction data. Photoluminescence studies showed that both ZnII and CdII complexes (1, 3, and 4) were moderately blue-green fluorescent in the solid state at room temperature upon excitation at 325 nm, although both the ligand and MnII complex 2 were nonemissive (Figure ). Three complexes displayed similar broad-band fluorescent emission with several apparent peaks centered at 470, 496, and 530 nm, respectively, but the relative intensities of the three emission bands were slightly different from each other. The emission at the blue-green region should be tentatively attributable to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer transition (LMCT) upon introduction of ZnII or CdII metal centers, on the basis of the similar luminescent ZnII or CdII complexes reported. The low-temperature (at 77 K) photoluminescence of three complexes revealed stronger broad-band emission in the range of 350−550 nm (see Supporting Information), and the emission peaks were slightly hypsochromic in comparison with the emission at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, a series of coordination polymers from a bispyridyl-based Schiff base ligand were synthesized in CH2Cl2−CH3OH medium and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. The results revealed that the molecular structures of four coordination complexes were profoundly influenced by the anions:  acetate anion drove the formation of 1D infinite molecular ladders, and nitrate anions induced two 3D cross-like arrays constructed directly from 1D single-chain coordination polymers. The study clearly indicates that counteranions with different coordination abilities or modes can play a key role in crystal engineering and reveals that an anion-template effect can take place in the coordination-driven self-assembly despite the use of different metal ions. Further investigations in the crystal engineering of anion-controlled self-assembly with other rigid bidentate ligands are under way in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a series of coordination polymers from a bispyridyl-based Schiff base ligand were synthesized in CH2Cl2-CH3OH medium and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. The results revealed that the molecular structures of four coordination complexes were profoundly influenced by the anions: acetate anion drove the formation of 1D infinite molecular ladders, and nitrate anions induced two 3D cross-like arrays constructed directly from 1D single-chain coordination polymers. The study clearly indicates that counteranions with different coordination abilities or modes can play  a key role in crystal engineering and reveals that an anion-template effect can take place in the coordination-driven self-assembly despite the use of different metal ions. Further investigations in the crystal engineering of anion-controlled self-assembly with other rigid bidentate ligands are under way in our laboratory.

Synthesis of Complex 1. A solution of L (0.210 g, 1 mmol) in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was slowly added to a solution of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.220 g, 1 mmol) in 5 mL of MeOH under stirring. The resulting mixture was left standing for two weeks at room temperature to give light yellow single crystals of 1. Yield:  80%, UV−vis(CHCl3), λmax/nm:  281, 303, 318, 350 (broad shoulder). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3395w, 1951s, 1605m, 1402s, 1335s, 1231s, 1032s, 968s, 818s, 683s, 515s. Anal. Calcd for C16H16N4O4Zn·CH3OH:  C, 47.96; H, 4.73; N, 13.16. Found:  C, 47.31; H, 4.64; N, 13.16.

Synthesis of Complex 2. The procedure is similar to that of 1 except for the replacement of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O with Mn(OAc)2·4H2O. Orange single crystals of 2 were harvested after several days. Yield:  65%, UV−vis(CHCl3), λ/nm:  275, 306, 317, 350 (broad shoulder). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3437w, 2354s, 1953s, 1597m, 1406s, 1312s, 1223s, 1060s, 972s, 814s, 680s, 513s. Anal. Calcd for C16H16N4O4Mn·CH3OH:  C, 49.16; H, 4.85; N, 13.49. Found:  C, 48.82; H, 4.88; N, 13.31.

Synthesis of Complex 3. The procedure is similar to that of 1 except for the replacement of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O with Zn(NO3)2·2H2O. Light yellow thin needles of 3 were harvested after three weeks. Yield:  88%, UV−vis(CHCl3), λ/nm:  282, 305, 345 (broad shoulder). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3433w, 2426s, 1615s, 1384s, 1227s, 1027m, 818s, 687s, 517s. Anal. Calcd for C12H10N6O6Zn·2H2O:  C, 33.08; H, 3.24; N, 19.29. Found:  C, 33.42; H, 3.12; N, 19.71.

Synthesis of Complex 4. The procedure is similar to that of 1 except for the replacement of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O with Cd(NO3)2·4H2O. Light yellow single crystals of 4 were harvested after two weeks. Yield:  72%, UV−vis(CHCl3), λ/nm:  280, 302, 346(broad shoulder). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3430w, 2395s, 1940s, 1610m, 1398s, 1233s, 1033m, 818s, 683s, 517s. Anal. Calcd for C12H10N6O6Cd·2H2O:  C, 29.86; H, 2.92; N, 17.41. Found:  C, 30.14; H, 3.17; N, 17.24.
